# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

None.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int = 10)
    lines = []
    current_line = ""
    for word in split(text, whitespace=true)
        if length(current_line) + length(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = ""
        end
        current_line *= word * ' '
    end
    push!(lines, current_line)  # add remaining line if any
    return join(lines, "\n")
end

# Example usage:
text = "Hello there, how are you today? I hope everything is fine. This is a longer text to test the wrapping functionality."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

This function splits the input `text` into words using `split(text, whitespace=true)`, which includes spaces and tabs as delimiters. It then iterates over these words, appending each to a current line. If the length of the current line plus the word exceeds the specified `text_width`, it adds a new line to the result and starts a new current line. After processing all words, it joins the lines with a newline character (`"\n"`) to create the wrapped text.

The example usage shows how to call the function with an initial text and prints out the wrapped text for demonstration purposes.
